item.title: MUrti pUjA history
item.description:
Source: TW

Temple worship in India also may have its origins in Bhāgavatism.

The famous Heliodorus pillar of Vidiśā/Besnagar was part of a temple complex in honor of Vāsudeva dating to the 3rd century BC, around the same time as the Śivaliṅga from Gudimallam temple.

The earliest anthropomorphic images of Indian cult/votive deities in India comes from Bhāgavatism (Tikula, coins of Agathocles, Malhar), Śaivism (Gudimallam Liṅga), and Yakṣa-cult (Parkham Maṇibhadra). These figures date to the 3rd - 2nd century BC.

item.title: भागवत-मत-प्राचीनता
item.description:
Aindra decline

Apart from the Bharhut and Sanchi Stupas (in which Indra is invariably depicted with ambiguous features and as subservient to Buddha rather than as an object of veneration), depictions of Indra are very sparse until almost five centuries after the time of Porus.

vyAkaraNa

According to Dāṇḍekar, the rule “Vāsudevārjunābhyāṃ vun” implies that the Vāsudeva-cult had largely come to supercede the “Aindra” Arjuna-cult (abhyarhitaṃ ca pūrvaṃ nipatati, “that which is [more] honoured in placed first”) at the time of Pāṇini, who lived in the Northwest (Śālātura) around the 4th or 5th century BC.
